comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Happy 122nd (is that a dog on the right of the picture)

Castletown Sounded like a fun place in the 1730's

Castletown became a fashionable place to be seen and was regarded as a rival to the Vice-Regal Court in Dublin Castle.  In the early 1730s Katherine (widow of William (Speaker) Conolly),  effectively ran a casino in the house when the Lord Lieutenant Dorset banned gambling.  Carriage races along the avenue were also a feature of Castletown entertainments and Katherine long partook fully in these activities with a host of rakish young men.  Upon her death in 1752, at the age of ninety, it was lamented that the huge house that used to be crowded with guests of all sorts was empty and forlorn.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Winter,  due to the bare trees and long shadows.  That narrows the date by 75%!

It is remarkable how the man and dog, and the open windows upset the classical symmetry.  Or do they add to the visual interest as you automatically look for imperfection?
